Review Toward high-sulfur-content, high-performance lithium-sulfur batteries: Review of materials and technologies Fulai Zhao a 1 ⁎ Jinhong Xue b 1 Wei Shao c Hui Yu d Wei Huang d Jian Xiao a d ⁎ a School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China School of Materials Science and Engineering Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, PR China b Basic Department, Jinci College of Shanxi Medical University, Taiyuan 030025, Shanxi, China Basic Department Jinci College of Shanxi Medical University Taiyuan 030025 Shanxi China Basic Department, Jinci College of Shanxi Medical University, Taiyuan 030025, PR China c School of Engineering, Westlake University, Hangzhou 310024, Zhejiang, China School of Engineering Westlake University Hangzhou 310024 Zhejiang China School of Engineering, Westlake University, 18 Shilongshan Road, Hangzhou 310024, PR China d School of Physics and Electronic Information, Shangrao Normal University, Shangrao 334001, Jiangxi, China School of Physics and Electronic Information Shangrao Normal University Shangrao 334001 Jiangxi China School of Physics and Electronic Information, Shangrao Normal University, Shangrao 334001, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract This review summarizes the important progress of five categories of sulfur cathode materials for high-sulfur-content and high-performance lithium sulfur batteries, emphasizes the importance of high sulfur content, and predicts the future development trend of sulfur cathode materials. Lithium sulfur batteries (LSBs) are recognized as promising devices for developing next-generation energy storage systems. In addition, they are attractive rechargeable battery systems for replacing lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) for commercial use owing to their higher theoretical energy density and lower cost compared to those of LIBs. However, LSBs are still beset with some persistent issues that prevent them from being used industrially, such as the unavoidable dissolution of lithium polysulfide intermediates during electrochemical reactions and large volume expansion (up to 80%) upon the formation of Li2S, resulting in serious battery life and safety limitations. In the process of solving these problems, it is necessary to maintain a high sulfur content in the cathode materials to ensure that the LSBs have high energy densities and excellent cycle performance. In this review, the novel preparation methods and cathode materials used for preparing LSBs in recent years are reviewed considering the sulfur content and cycle performance. In addition, the problems and difficulties in practically applying cathode materials are described, and the development trend is discussed. Keywords Lithium sulfur batteries Cathode material High sulfur content Cycle performance 1 Introduction With the continuous development of modern science and technology, electronic equipment has evolved, becoming lightweight, mobile, and miniaturized. Thus, there is an increasing demand for lightweight and high-energy–density batteries [1,2]. Until now, lithium batteries have mainly been based on lithium composite materials in modern applications [3,4]. In the past few decades, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have dominated the commercial battery market because of their high battery voltage, low self-discharge rate, and stable cycle performance [3]. However, it is difficult to meet the application needs of emerging markets, such as long-range electric vehicles or large smart grids, using LIBs; this is owing to their low energy density (only 100–220 W h kg−1) and high cost [5,6]. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop alternative energy storage systems that are thin, low cost, and have a high energy density to meet the increasing energy demands [7]. Lithium sulfur batteries (LSBs) are one of the best candidates for use in next-generation energy storage systems owing to their high theoretical energy density and the natural abundance of sulfur [8–10]. Generally, traditional LSBs are composed of a lithium anode, elemental sulfur cathode, and ether-based electrolyte. A high-capacity lithium electrode (3840 mA h g−1) coupled with a sulfur electrode (1675 mA h g−1) produces an average battery voltage of 2.2 V and theoretical energy density of 2567 W h kg−1 [11]. Thus, LSBs can store substantially more energy than LIBs. However, due to their short battery life, LSB technology has not yet been commercialized. In addition, the promotion of LSBs is hampered by the irreversible loss of battery capacity caused by the insulation of elemental sulfur, poor stability of sulfur electrodes, and safety problems resulting from the volume expansion of LSBs during electrochemical reactions [12–15]. To overcome these limitations, significant progress has been achieved through the improvement and innovation of electrodes and electrolytes. As the most important component of LSBs, sulfur cathodes have received considerable attention in recent years. Owing to the increasing research on the modification of cathode materials for LSBs and technological improvements in recent years, it is possible to prolong the cycle life of sulfur cathodes and obtain high rate performances. Nevertheless, for LSBs, the premise for maintaining an advantage in energy density is the high sulfur-content and sulfur utilization in the cathode. Researchers have conducted extensive theoretical and experimental research in pursuit of high-sulfur-content cathodes and made many significant breakthroughs. However, among the numerous reviews on LSB cathode materials, there are few systematic reviews on high-sulfur-content cathode materials with high performance. In the present review, the progress of novel sulfur cathode materials, mainly carbon nanotubes (CNTs), graphene, porous carbon, metal compounds, polymers, and other sulfur host materials, is summarized from the aspects of capacity and sulfur content in the cathode. In particular, the latest cathode materials with high capacities (initial capacity >1000 mA h g−1) and cycle lives (>100 cycles) are discussed. In addition, the future trend of sulfur cathode materials is predicted. The importance of high sulfur content for LSBs is emphasized. Finally, the advantages and shortcomings of various high-sulfur-content sulfur cathode materials are summarized, and the future development direction of sulfur cathode materials is discussed. 2 Basic working principle of lithium sulfur batteries Because of the particularity of cathode materials, the charging and discharging principles of LSBs and traditional LIBs are significantly different [16–21]. As shown in Scheme 1 , a typical LSB consists of a lithium metal anode, an organic electrolyte, a separator, and a sulfur cathode. During the discharge process, the lithium metal of the anode is converted into lithium ions (Li+) by losing electrons and migrates to the cathode by diffusion in the electrolyte. The electrons lost by lithium move to the cathode through an external circuit. When electrons and Li+ ions reach the sulfur cathode, elemental sulfur begins to be reduced, producing a series of electrolyte-soluble long-chain lithium polysulfide (LiPS) intermediates, namely Li2S x , where x = 4–8, which are further converted into insoluble short-chain LiPSs (Li2S x ; x = 1–2). During the charging process, the short-chain LiPSs are converted into long-chain LiPSs through the reverse reaction before being converted back to elemental sulfur [21,22]. However, under this mechanism, LSBs suffer from serious problems. These include the severe polarization and low rate performance caused by the insulating properties of sulfur and short-chain LiPSs, significant loss of reversible capacity caused by the shuttle effect of long-chain LiPSs, which shortens the cycle life of the battery, and battery safety problems caused by the dendrites generated by lithium metal electrodes [23–25]. As the key component, the sulfur cathode plays a decisive role in the electrochemical performance of LSBs. Therefore, the defects of sulfur cathodes should be solved before LSBs can be applied commercially. For the improvement of the sulfur cathode, most studies have primarily centered on limiting the dissolution or formation of LiPSs by inhibiting the shuttle effect of polysulfides. There are also studies aimed at preventing the formation of soluble long-chain polysulfides so that sulfur is directly converted into insoluble short-chain sulfides, thereby altering the mechanism of lithium-sulfur reaction to enhance cathode performance. It is suitable for powering small electronic devices such as smartphones, cameras, electric bicycles, and low-speed electric vehicles due to the high stability and safety generated by inhibiting or preventing the dissolution of LiPSs. Recent studies have demonstrated that LiPSs must be dissolved for LSBs to achieve high performance [26,27]. The focus of research should be on the rapid conversion of soluble LiPSs, and the speed of liquid–solid conversion and subsequent solid-solid conversion of intermediates should be increased through the use of catalysts that accelerate the kinetics of sulfur reduction reaction [28]. Extreme environments, such as space power systems, polar/deep-water exploration, and high-altitude environments, can benefit from LSBs with an enhanced kinetic performance of dissolved LiPSs. Consequently, the soluble or insoluble state of LiPSs in LSBs should be designed in the future based on the actual application scenarios. A variety of physical and chemical methods have been developed to coat and fix elemental sulfur and achieve the modification of sulfur cathode materials. These measures taken are to inhibit the dissolution of lithium polysulfide, promote the rapid conversion of dissolved lithium polysulfide, and reform the lithium-sulfur reaction mechanism. Next, we will discuss the research status and development direction of high-performance LSBs from the perspective of various modification methods of cathode materials. 3 Cathode materials for lithium sulfur batteries To overcome the non-conductive defect of elemental sulfur and improve electrochemical performance, doping conductive additives, such as acetylene black, carbon black, and super-P, into sulfur electrode materials is an effective way to improve the conductivity of sulfur electrode and endow it with high rate performance and long cycle life. However, these methods have often come at the expense of reducing the sulfur content of the electrodes. In general, the energy density of LSBs is closely related to the sulfur content. Furthermore, the content of sulfur in the electrode should be higher than 50% to maintain its advantage over LIBs in terms of energy density [29,30]. For the LSB system, the energy density of the battery is determined by the sulfur-loading in the electrode (the sulfur mass per unit area). The improvement in energy density can be achieved by increasing the sulfur loading. In general, an increase in sulfur loading will lead to electrode thickening of the LSB. If the structure of the electrode is not improved, the thickness of the electrode has a negative effect on the cycle performance and rate performance of the battery [31–33]. When the cathode material has a high sulfur content, LSB has a higher energy density than LIB even under low active material loading. Consequently, high sulfur content is essential for the lightness and high energy density of LSB. Fortunately, a variety of reliable methods have been developed to prepare the composite sulfur cathodes of LSBs with high sulfur content and high performances. 3.1 Carbon nanotube As a one-dimensional (1D) carbon material, CNTs have high aspect ratios and conductivities. In addition, they can form an interconnected network that enables sulfur cathode materials with long-range conductivity, which is desired in LSB applications [34]. However, due to its closed end, it is difficult for sulfur to penetrate the inner cavity of CNTs, which cannot effectively inhibit the diffusion of LiPSs. Therefore, to make full use of the advantages of CNTs to effectively inhibit the shuttle effect of LiPSs and improve the performance of LSBs, it is necessary to design the physical and chemical structures of CNTs. The overall contact between sulfur and CNTs can be improved through different forms of CNTs. For example, amorphous CNTs can be conveniently penetrated by sulfur via capillarity. Wang et al. [35] prepared disordered CNTs (DCNTs) using an anodic aluminum oxide (AAO) membrane as a template and polyacrylonitrile (PAN) as a carbon precursor. DCNTs have graphite clusters and amorphous carbon structure, which can be penetrated by sulfur vapor. Therefore, sulfur was impregnated into the DCNTs by CS2-assisted impregnation followed by heating at a temperature of 500 °C in vacuum, in which an S8 molecule was broken down to S6 or S2 and formed SC bonds. Because at high temperatures, around 600 °C in vacuum, the sulfur vapor is in the form of a significant fraction of S6 (58.8 wt%) and S2 (16.4 wt%) molecules [36]. S6 and S2 molecules are more reactive because they possess a greater fraction of sulfur terminal atoms [37], so S6 and S2 molecules are connected to carbon in the form of CS bonds. Their small size and strong bonding with carbon can more easily diffuse into the small voids of DCNTs and even intercalate into the graphitic clusters of DCNTs [38,39]. Therefore, sulfur might mainly exist as S6 and S2 with strong CS bonding in defects and graphite layers of the as-prepared sulfur-impregnated DCNTs at 500 °C (SDCNT-500), which was confirmed by the equilibrium potential versus capacity curves. As a result, the vaporized sulfur was incorporated into the graphitized carbon layers of DCNTs and the smaller voids/defects in amorphous carbon of DCNTs that liquid electrolyte could not directly reach. At the same time, heating treatment decomposes the S8 molecule into S6 or S2 and makes the sulfur-carbon bond, which changes the reaction mechanism of LSB by altering the dissolvable LiPS intermediate products. Therefore, the SDCNT-500 cathode showed a capacity retention of 72.9% after 100 cycles and Coulombic efficiency of 96%. Yan et al. [40] immobilized 68 wt% sulfur on the surface of functionalized CNTs at 300 °C. As shown in Fig. 1 (a), CNTs were refluxed in a mixture of concentrated sulfuric acid and nitric acid to remove amorphous carbon and form oxygen-containing groups on the surfaces of CNTs. Then, 68 wt% of sulfur was successfully anchored on the surfaces of oxygen-containing groups functionalized CNTs via forming CS and OS covalent bonds through a solvent exchange method combined with low-temperature treatment (300 °C) to form sulfurized CNTs (SCNTs). The characterization results revealed that the synthesized SCNTs agglomerated due to the van der Waals interactions, forming a 3D interconnected framework with many nanopores that served as ionic- and electric-conductive channels and accommodated high amounts of sulfur. Moreover, a large amount of elemental sulfur reacted with CNTs to form a cross-linked porous SCNT skeleton with short sulfur chains (–S x –, x ≤ 4), which made most of the sulfur in SCNTs have an uncommon monoclinic phase rather than a typical orthorhombic phase, and monoclinic sulfur was still very stable after storage at room temperature for 30 days. Benefiting from these advantages of SCNTs, sulfur was well confined by the nanopores and covalent bonds of SCNTs, and the oxygen-containing surface groups enhanced the interactions between CNT and sulfur and improved the physical and chemical adsorption of sulfur particles and LiPSs during electrochemical cycling. Thus, the developed LSBs based on SCNT cathodes exhibited high performance and cyclic stability, i.e., high reversible capacities of 1180 mA h g−1 after 300 cycles at 0.25 C, 799 mA h g−1 after 600 cycles at 0.75 C, 810 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles at 1 C, and 400 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles at 2 C. The diameter of ordinary CNTs is usually very small and the tube wall is impermeable. It is difficult for sulfur to penetrate the internal space of CNTs. The tube-in-tube structure combines the advantages of CNTs and hollow carbon tubes with larger diameters, which could potentially solve this problem. Wang et al. [41] reported a carbon with a tube-in-tube structure that was applied to a encapsulate sulfur material with a sulfur content of 85.2 wt% (Fig. 1b). Many small-diameter CNTs are grown in large-diameter ones, which significantly enhances the electrical contact, reduces the internal shuttle effect, and buffers the large volume variation in sulfur cathodes. The CNT-encapsulated CNT/sulfur composite exhibited a reversible capacity of 1193 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.1 C. The reversible capacities were 1146, 1121, and 954 mA h g−1 under large current rates of 1, 2, and 5 C, respectively, after 150 cycles. Choi and Kim et al. [42] developed an encapsulated sulfur electrode (S@C NW) in which sulfur nanowires (NWs) were well aligned and encapsulated inside the CNTs, which were synthesized using AAO as a template (Fig. 1c and d). Moreover, most of the sulfur fixed in nanoscale CNTs exists in the form of monoclinic S8, which is different from the common orthorhombic S8 at room temperature and will not form soluble polysulfides during battery operation. Therefore, the S@C NW electrode exhibited a high initial discharge capacity of 1139 mA h g−1 at 5 C after 1000 cycles and provided a capacity retention rate of 75.8% (Fig. 1e). Multiwalled CNTs (MWCNTs) has internal and external hollow microstructures that provide good electron/ion transport paths and highly dynamic reactive interfaces. Therefore, Chen et al. [43] developed a sulfur uniformly coated three-dimensional (3D) MWCNTs (S/MWCNT) nanomicrosphere to accommodate sulfur or polysulfide, as shown in Fig. 1(f). In addition to the abovementioned two advantages, the S/MWCNT is also adaptable to volume changes during the cycle and restricts much more electrolytes to the electrode, thereby obtaining high remaining capacities and long cycle lives. The functional groups stemmed from the surface of MWCNTs provide a chemical gradient that delays the diffusion of polysulfide from the electrode, which enhances the integrity of the electrochemical reaction and produces an acceptable reversible capacity. As a cathode material of LSBs, the S/MWCNT achieved a high reversible capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles at a current density of 0.3 A g−1. Even at high current densities, it maintained capacities of 780 and 650 mA h g−1 at 0.5 and 1 A g−1, respectively, after 200 cycles. Based on the advantages of MWCNTs, Su et al. [44] synthesized a flexible self-weaving sulfur–MWCNT composite cathode without binders and current collectors (Fig. 1g) to maintain the integrity of the electrode and confine soluble polysulfide intermediates within the electrode structure. The sulfur–MWCNT composite cathode delivered high capacities of 1352 and 1012 mA h g−1 at 1 and 4 C, respectively. Wang et al. [45] developed nano sulfur/super-aligned CNTs (PVP@S-SACNT) encapsulated by polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) composite cathodes via a solution-based method, which is also a binder/current collector free electrode (Fig. 1h). Compared to ordinary CNTs, the super-aligned feature, large aspect ratio, clean surface, and ability to form robust and continuous networks due to the strong van der Waals forces between the tubes and bundles make SACNTs a 3D conductive network with superior mechanical strength and flexibility, which can provide a continuous transport path for electrons and lithium ions and makes them ideal containers for accommodating and capturing polysulfides. Therefore, the PVP@S-SACNT composite electrode showed excellent cyclic stability with an initial discharge capacity of 1303 mA h g−1, which was maintained at 856 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at 1 C (Fig. 1i). Heteroatom doping and modification is an effective means of enhancing the anchoring effect of CNTs on polysulfides, and it inhibits the shuttle effect of LiPSs. For example, nitrogen-doping can improve the adsorption performance toward LiPSs and the electrochemical activity of CNTs without sacrificing the conductivity. Peng et al. [46] introduced nitrogen-doped CNTs (NCNTs) as conductive carriers for the active sulfur during cycling process (Fig. 2 a). According to first-principles calculations, nitrogen-doping enhances the binding energy between the carbon host and sulfur-containing guest. The as-prepared NCNT-S composite has a high sulfur content of more than 65 wt%. When applied to an LSB cathode, the as-prepared NCNT-S electrode exhibited a high capacity of 1370 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C. At a high current density of 1 C, it delivered a capacity of 964 mA h g−1 and maintained 70% of its initial capacity after 200 cycles. Oxygen-doping using oxygen-containing groups is also effective in trapping polysulfides. The oxygen-modified surface may react with sulfur to form an SO bond, which acts as a chemical anchor to capture polysulfides [47]. Wang et al. [48] obtained a boron-oxygen co-doped porous carbon composite (BOC@CNT) as a sulfur host (BOC@CNT/S) by the in-situ growth of borate ester covalent organic framework (COF) materials on the surface of CNTs and subsequent calcination at high temperatures (Fig. 2b). The BOC@CNT/S composite electrode has good conductivity and polysulfide anchoring ability, which effectively suppresses the capacity decay during cycling. The BOC@CNT/S composite with 68.5% sulfur exhibits an excellent electrochemical performance as a cathode material for LSBs, including a high specific capacity of 1077 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.2 C (Fig. 2c) and long cycle stability with a remained capacity of 794 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles at 1 C (Fig. 2d). The doping of Co, Fe, Mo, Ni, and other metals can not only enhance the adsorption of CNTs toward polysulfides but also reduce the diffusion barrier of lithium ions and promote the deposition/decomposition of lithium sulfide. Thus, it effectively suppresses the shuttle effect and improves the redox reaction kinetics. Li et al. [49] prepared Fe/Fe3C modified cotton-derived MWCNTs (Fe/Fe3C-MWCNTs) via a vapor-liquid-solid and solid-liquid-solid combination process (Fig. 2e), where cotton textiles were converted to activated carbon textiles (ACTs) and served as both the substrate and carbon source. During the formation of CNTs, Fe/Fe3C was uniformly wrapped in CNTs to form an effective electrochemical adsorption catalyst (Fig. 2f and g). This CNT structure integrates physical confinement, chemical adsorption, and electrochemical catalysis at the microscopic scale. The obtained LSB has excellent electrochemical performance. This is mainly attributed to the excellent mechanical and chemical properties of Fe/Fe3C-MWCNTs, which reduces the deformation of CNTs and inhibits the dissolution of polysulfides. With 62.3 wt% sulfur-content, the as-prepared Fe/Fe3C-MWCNT@ACT/S composite possessed a high initial specific capacity of 877 mA h g−1 at 1C, which increased to 948 mA h g−1 after 122 cycles, and an ultra-long life of more than 1000 charge/discharge cycles, with an extremely low-capacity decay rate of 0.0496% per cycle (Fig. 2h). Ren and Zhang et al. [50] prepared CoSe2-decorated hollow nitrogen-doped CNTs (CoSe2/hNCTs) using polypyrrole (PPy)-derived nitrogen-doped CNTs as a template (Fig. 2i), which were used as the sulfur hosts to prepare sulfur cathode materials. The CoSe2/hNCTs composite reasonably combines the conductivity of carbon-based materials with the polarity and electrocatalytic activity of selenides. The hollow tubular structure is conducive to the transmission of lithium ions and electrons and can reduce the shuttle effect of polysulfides through physical confinement, making the electrode material exhibit excellent electrochemical performance. The as-fabricated CoSe2/hNCTs/S cathode has a high sulfur content of 80% and provided a satisfactory lithium storage performance with reversible capacities of 1156 and 640 mA h g−1 at 0.5 and 5 C, respectively (Fig. 2j). At the same time, the cathode exhibited an excellent cycle stability and the capacity decay rate per cycle was 0.069 % after 1000 cycles at 1 C rate (Fig. 2k). CNTs have the advantage of excellent conductivity, so the sulfur cathode prepared using CNTs as host materials can easily show high capacities and excellent rate performances. However, to significantly improve the sulfur-content and long cycle stability, specialized CNT structure design and treatments, including doping, modification, and multi-level compounding, are unavoidable. These complex preparation processes coupled with the price disadvantages of CNTs have led to a significant increase in the manufacturing cost of high-performance LSB cathode materials, which is not conducive to the commercial application of LSBs. The preparation method of CNT composites using biomass materials as carbon sources is an ideal sustainable and low-cost method for the design and fabrication of CNT-based sulfur hosts, such as the CNT composite materials derived from cotton [39]. Therefore, more efforts should pay attention to these areas in the future. 3.2 Graphene As a typical two-dimensional (2D) material, graphene has an ultra-high specific surface area and conductivity, abundant surface groups, and controllable active sites. In addition, it is considered as one of the best candidates for the host material of LSB cathode materials [51–53]. However, the open 2D planar structure of graphene cannot effectively constrain the diffusion of LiPSs, which leads to the rapid capacity decline of LSBs. Moreover, the π–π interaction between graphene sheets causes these sheets to be stacked on each other, which greatly reduces their actual specific surface area and cannot fully exert their performance advantages. Therefore, the application of graphene on sulfur cathode materials is mainly in the form of surface chemically-modified graphene and graphene-based composite materials [54,55]. To exploit the advantages of graphene in LSBs, Ji et al. [56] used a chemical method to immobilize sulfur and LiPSs through reactive functional groups on graphene oxide. Strong interactions between graphene oxide and sulfur or polysulfides enabled LSBs with high reversible capacities of 950–1400 mA h g−1 at 0.1C. Hydrophobic graphene is tightly wrapped on the surface of the hydrophobic carbon based on the changing hydrophilicity of graphene during the reduction process. Therefore, graphene-coated carbon/sulfur composites were prepared for LSBs by Li et al. [57]. The initial discharge capacity of the obtained composites was approximately 1578.3 mA h g−1 (0.15 A g−1), which is higher than that of pure carbon/sulfur composites. Similarly, Tang et al. [58] prepared nitrogen-doped CNTs/graphene/sulfur composites with an initial discharge capacity of 1152 mA h g−1 and the capacity remained nearly 76% after 80 cycles. All the aforementioned composites exhibit excellent properties. However, these battery materials have not been tested for more than 100 cycles. Song et al. [59] reported a highly folded nitrogen-doped graphene sheet with an ultra-high pore volume of approximately 5.4 cm3 g−1 that was prepared by a simple thermally induced expansion method without a template (Fig. 3 a). Notably, the folded graphene sheets were interwoven rather than stacked, resulting in nitrogen-rich active sites. The as-prepared LSB using the obtained graphene sheets as the carrier of sulfur and an intermediate layer achieved a high capacity of 1227 mA h g−1 and a long cycle life for 300 cycles with a capacity retention of 75% at a high sulfur content of 80 wt%. This was ascribed to the unique pore structure and adsorption capacity of nitrogen-doped polysulfide. Gao and Li et al. [60] designed a novel 3D self-woven CNT-GN composite material using 1D CNTs and 2D graphite sheets (GN) by one-pot pyrolysis (Fig. 3b). Owing to the insertion and distribution of CNTs between graphene sheets, the GN-CNT 3D material not only provides a large specific surface area but also possesses an open network and porous structure that are favorable for electron and Li ion transport. The Co2+ randomly distributed in the composite or on the top of the CNT has a strong chemical bond with sulfur. During the charging and discharging process, Co can adsorb polysulfides and convert long-chain sulfides to small molecular sulfides. Therefore, the 3D structured graphene-based composite sulfur cathode material can support up to 82% sulfur. Its initial discharge capacity is as high as 1373.8 mA h g−1 and the capacity remains at 836.5 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles. Recently, Chen et al. [61] developed a Ni2Co nanoalloy-decorated flower-like reduced graphene oxide (rGO) microassembly (Ni2Co@rGO) (Fig. 3c), which serves as a host matrix for the anodes and cathodes of LSBs with a sulfur content of approximately 74 wt%. The tightly-packed flower-like microspherical structure of rGO matrix endows strong structural integrity against volume changes during cycling and excellent long-range conductivity to facilitate rapid reaction kinetics, while the voids between the wrinkled nanosheets provide channels for fast ion/mass transfer. Moreover, combining computational, physicochemical, and electrochemical studies, they revealed the strong adsorption capacity against polysulfide shuttling and excellent catalytic activity for sulfur conversion of Ni2Co nanoalloys. At the same time, the complex architecture facilitates electron/ion transport and highly exposed active interfaces. The abovementioned advantages of Ni2Co@rGO jointly promote fast and durable sulfur electrochemistry, with the smallest capacity decrease of only 0.034% per cycle and a rate capability up to 5 C over 500 cycles. Furthermore, Ni2Co@rGO as the anode matrix resolves the redox behavior of Li, which benefits from its enhanced lithiophilic ability and reduced local current density. Yang and Guo et al. [62] developed a facile template-free self-cages nanochemical approach for the large-scale synthesis of high-performance sulfonated graphene@sulfur (SG@S) yolk-shell nanocomposites, as shown in Fig. 3(d). The as-prepared SG@S yolk-shell material has a high sulfur-content that exceeds 85 wt% and can achieve physical confinement and chemical adsorption of polysulfides. The sulfur electrode prepared with this composite material has a high electrical conductivity, structural stability, and excellent polysulfide-trapping ability. Even after 2000 cycles at 0.5 C, the LSBs prepared with this material maintained a stable capacity of 602 mA h g−1, with a capacity decay of only 0.019% per cycle. At the same time, the self-discharge behavior of the battery is also significantly suppressed, resulting in a longer shelf life for the battery. In order to break through the slow kinetic barrier and polysulfide shuttle of the sulfur cathode under high sulfur-content conditions to achieve continuous high sulfur utilization in extended charge-discharge cycles, Shao et al. [63] effectively incorporated a large amount of sulfur (80.3 wt%) into carbon nanofibers (CNFs) network through a simple ball milling process to obtain a SG/sulfur (SG/S) composite, in which vertical graphene nanoflakes (VG) were grown on the CNF network by the chemical vapor deposition (CVD) method, as shown in Fig. 3(e). The CNF network composed of high-quality graphene provides a continuous and lasting channel for the effective transport of lithium ions and electrons. In addition, the in-situ sulfur-doping generated by the ball milling alloying effect promotes the affinity with the entire sulfur species to prevent sulfur loss and the high active sites promote the sulfur redox reaction during the cycling. This leads to remarkable rate performance and excellent cycle stability, as well as large-area capacities. With a high sulfur area loading of 8.0 mg cm−2 and an electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) ratio of 8 μL mg−1, the SG/S cathode delivered an area capacity of 5.21 mA h cm−2 at 0.2 C, corresponding to an energy density of 1276.4 W h kg−1. At present, graphene-based sulfur host materials experience problems such as high preparation cost and complicated preparation process. The reduction in conductivity and weakening of the shuttle effect suppression under high sulfur-loading are also problems to be solved in practical applications. The solution is to synthesize graphene and its composites using green synthetic technology and organic raw materials and to combine them with other low-cost sulfur host materials or additives to further reduce costs and improve the electrochemical performance of sulfur cathodes. 3.3 Porous carbon materials Supporting sulfur in a porous carbon matrix material with good electronic and ionic conductivity while limiting the diffusion of polysulfides is a solution to the poor conductivity of sulfur and short-chain polysulfides, shuttle effect of soluble long-chain polysulfides, and volume expansion problems. It not only provides a highly conductive and structurally stable electrochemical reaction framework for sulfur and discharge products but can also effectively alleviate the diffusion of soluble polysulfide ions into the electrolyte, thereby improving the discharge capacity, rate performance, and cycling life of LSBs [64,65]. At present, the most studied porous carbon materials include activated carbon, mesoporous carbon, ultra-small microporous carbon, multi-stage porous carbon, hollow carbon spheres, and hollow carbon fibers [66–68]. Lee and Nazar et al. [69] used highly ordered mesoporous carbon CMK-3 to physically coat sulfur. The results suggested that the CMK-3/S cathode material significantly enhanced the performances of the battery at a sulfur-content of 70 wt% and the reversible capacity reached 1320 mA h g−1. Li et al. [70] systematically explored the pore size effect of mesoporous carbon and determined that the specific capacity and cyclic stability of the cathode material were improved by optimizing the pore size and sulfur-content. A series of mesoporous carbon materials with pore sizes of 22, 12, 7, and 3 nm and pore volumes ranging from 1.3 to 4.8 cm3 g−1 were synthesized. When applied to sulfur-containing host materials, the larger pore volume resulted in a higher maximum sulfur loading, but when the pores are filled with sulfur, the battery performance of various mesoporous carbon-sulfur composites is comparable. In contrast, partial sulfur filling (i.e., the pores are only partially filled with sulfur) improved electrical contact between sulfur and mesoporous carbon and electrical and ionic transport during the electrochemical reaction, thereby enhancing the initial discharge capacity and cycle stability of the battery. To achieve partial sulfur filling, they designed a mesoporous carbon-sulfur composite with a large pore volume (22 nm, 4.8 cm3 g−1) and controlled sulfur content (50 wt%). Since the surface functionalization of mesoporous carbon by commercial Clevios P can inhibit polysulfide dissolution in the electrolyte, polysulfide dissolution is inhibited. Clevios P surface functionalized mesoporous carbon–sulfur cathode material with an initial capacity of 1400 mA h g−1 and a residual capacity of 840 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles was subsequently prepared. In addition, Chen et al. [71] and Tao et al. [72] also analyzed the relationship between different pore sizes and battery performance (Fig. 4 a). The results were consistent with the previous investigation reported by Li [70]. Therefore, the development of porous carbon-based composite materials with macroporous volumes and optimized pore structures is crucial. A double-peak distributed porous carbon with a high sulfur-loading rate of cathode materials was synthesized using an evaporation-induced self-assembly method for LSBs by He et al. [73], while the required bimunal distribution was obtained by optimizing the ratio of carbon/silica/surfactant. The results implied that the initial capacity was 995 mA h g−1 at 1 C. After 100 cycles, the residual capacity was 550 mA h g−1. Wei et al. [74] prepared macroporous carbon/sulfur cathode materials with hierarchical pores using KOH activation. Although the initial capacity of the macroporous carbon/sulfur cathode material was 1265 mA h g−1, the capacity was only 643 mA h g−1 after 50 cycles. This system not only promotes electron and ion transportation but also shortens the dispersion distance of lithium ions in the electrolyte, which promotes a rapid reaction rate and contributes to the rapid kinetic reaction. Hwang et al. [75] successfully synthesized a sulfurized-PAN-wrapped porous carbon–sulfur composite using a dissolution-reprecipitation method followed by thermal treatment (denoted as S/rSP@SPAN, Fig. 4b). As a result, the obtained composite cathode material possesses 54.5 % sulfur-content and retained approximately 83 % of the stable reversible capacity (1251 mA h g−1) over 100 cycles at 0.1 C. Manthiram et al. [76] designed a gel electrode composed of a porous carbon impregnated with polysulfide and doped with oxygen and nitrogen, as well as an independent, continuous, and highly conductive 3D graphene film as a charge transfer network. This gel cathode enables the efficient utilization of sulfur in a separate cathode and electrolyte-deficient environment, such as 240 mg mL−1 electrolyte, and the amount of sulfur used was as much as 83 wt%. Meanwhile, the initial capacity of the gel cathode was 822 mA h g−1 and the residual rate of the capacity was 91% after 50 cycles compared to the second cycle. Hou et al. [77] designed a porous structure (Si/SiO2@C) of carbon spheres coated with Si/SiO2, as shown in Fig. 4(c). A complex network cross-linked structure is formed inside this structure that differs from the traditional porous carbon structure. It can adsorb polysulfides through physical adsorption and negatively charged polysulfide anions through electrostatic interaction, which can better alleviate the shuttle effect. In addition, this structure has a high specific surface area, which can expose more active sites. It overcame the problem of low sulfur-content and improved the transportation of lithium ions, thus improving the transmission rate of lithium ions and accelerating the reaction kinetics inside the battery. Owing to the special structural characteristics of Si/SiO2@CS, 69.6% sulfur-content can be achieved. Its initial specific capacity was 1215 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C, 1002 mA h g−1 at 0.5 C, and 825 mA h g−1 at 2 C. In addition, it had a very low decay rate of only 0.063% per cycle over 500 cycles, showing relatively high cycle stability (Fig. 4d). To increase the sulfur-content of carbon porous materials and make better use of active materials, Geng et al. [78] developed an in-situ preparation method of 3D porous graphitic carbon (PGC), as shown in Fig. 4(e). Sulfur nanoparticles were synthesized in-situ on 3D PGC to fabricate a high sulfur content composite 3D S@PGC for LSB cathodes. The 3D S@PGC has a maximum sulfur-content of 90% owing to its unique 3D structure and excellent rate performance because of the uniform distribution of sulfur on the 3D porous carbon and the presence of strong covalent bonds. At a maximum charge/discharge rate of 5 C, the specific capacity remains as high as 500 mA h g−1 and the cycling is stable (Fig. 4f). Moreover, the composite showed stable cycling performance over 1000 cycles at 2 C, retaining a high specific capacity of 670 mA h g−1 after cycling (Fig. 4g). Studies have demonstrated that nitrogen-doped carbon was an effective method to improve the electrochemical properties of sulfur cathodes in LSBs. Wang et al. [79] confirmed that nitrogen-doped carbon exhibited strong adsorption for lithium polysulfide. The functional groups stemmed from nitrogen-doped carbon can be directly applied to absorb soluble Li2S x without the heat treatment of sulfur and doped carbon materials. Hence, the material had an exceptionally strong adsorption capacity and can effectively adsorb the polysulfide of lithium on the cathode. Hollow-doped carbon materials can alleviate volume expansion owing to their large cavities and heteroatom-doping can increase the binding ability of polysulfides to achieve a high specific capacity and long cycle life of LSBs. However, hollow carbon materials are mostly isolated, which increases the interface resistance of the material, and the looseness of the stack also reduces the volume energy density of the battery. Qiu et al. [80] prepared a well-designed nitrogen-doped hierarchical 3D porous carbon (NHPC) that showed excellent electrochemical performance using a novel metal–organic aerogel as a precursor. The as-prepared S/NHPC-1cathode delivered an initial specific capacity of 1341 mA h g−1 at 0.5 C and a high rate capability of 353 mA h g−1 at 5 C. The electrode also exhibited stable cycling performance over 500 cycles at 1 C with a remaining capacity of 354 mA h g−1, which corresponds to an ultra-low fading ratio of 0.08% per cycle. The excellent performance is attributed to the improved adsorption of LiPS by nitrogen doping. In addition, the hierarchical porous structure limits the soluble LiPS and 1D rod-like integrated carbon network to provide “green channels” for electrons. Wei et al. [81] also synthesized nitrogen-doped carbon materials with hierarchical pore structures using a composite template method that combines ZnCl2 salt and SiO2 hard templates, as shown in Fig. 4(h). The nitrogen–carbon precursor o-phenylenediamine (oPD) is converted to a 3D interconnected hierarchical nitrogen-doped carbon material through chemical oxidation polymerization, high-temperature heat treatment, etching, and other steps. It has a high degree of graphitization, good conductivity, a large number of micropores and small-sized mesopores, and an interconnected 3D macroporous skeleton network. As a cathode material, it can improve the utilization rate of the active material sulfur, inhibit the shuttle effect, and solve the volume expansion and contraction of sulfur. Therefore, it exhibited good cycle stability and excellent rate performance with 70% sulfur-content. The initial capacity was 834 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C and a capacity of 520 mA h g−1 was retained after 300 cycles. The attenuation rate per cycle is as low as 0.13% and the Coulomb efficiency exceeded 98.1% (Fig. 4i). Wang et al. [82] developed interconnected hollow structure heteroatom-doped carbon materials as sulfur host materials to improve the performance of LSBs. As shown in Fig. 4(j), they used an imidazolium-based ionic polymer (ImIP)-coated zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) core–shell structure as a precursor, introduced dicyandiamide (DCA) ions by an anion exchange strategy, and induced the decomposition and cross-linking of the core–shell structure by high-temperature carbonization to successfully prepare a class of interconnected hollow nitrogen-doped porous carbon materials (HNPCs). They used the ZIF-8-coated core–shell structure with an imidazole-based ionic polymer (ImIP) as a precursor to prepare a class of interconnected HNPCs by high-temperature carbonization-induced decomposition and crosslinking of the core–shell structure. The HNPC structure can reduce the interface resistance of the material, enhance the adsorption capacity of polysulfides, and improve the utilization of active materials. The as-prepared HNPC-900-65S-based cathode (65 wt% sulfur-content) achieved a specific capacity of 562 mA h g−1 after 800 cycles at a rate of 2 C (Fig. 4k). The electrochemical performance is significantly better than that of traditional heteroatom-doped carbon materials. Even the HNPC-900-78S electrode prepared by increasing the weight percentage of sulfur from 65 to 78 wt% exhibited a high capacity and excellent rate performance. These studies can provide new research ideas for the design of high-performance cathode materials. Compared with carbon nanomaterials, such as graphene and CNTs, porous carbon materials not only have excellent electrical conductivity but also have the advantages of a large pore volume, high specific surface areas, tailorability, and low cost [67,83,84], which makes them favorable for use in industrial applications. Although the performance of LSBs has been improved, there are still some challenges in improving the sulfur-content of porous carbon. For the composites with high sulfur-content, the poor cycle life at high charge–discharge rates remains problematic. The appropriate addition of multifunctional additives and reasonable structural design are key to solving these problems. 3.4 Metal compounds A sulfur cathode based on metal compound nanomaterials, such as metal oxides, sulfides, carbides, borides, nitrides, and phosphides, and metal–organic frameworks [85–91] can not only suppress the shuttle effect but also regulate the dissolution of lithium polysulfide, accelerate its transformation kinetics, and improve sulfur utilization [91–94]. For example, polar functional groups can immobilize Li2S n by forming strong chemical bonds [95] and the high catalytic activity of metal compounds can promote the transformation and reaction of these LiPSs [96]. 3.4.1 Metal oxides and sulfides TiO2 [97,98], Al2O3 [99], NiFe2O4 [100], Fe3O4 [101], Co3O4 [102], Nb2O5 [103], MgO [104], CeO2 [105], ZnO [106], and SnO2 [107] are typical representatives of metal oxide host materials for LSBs [92,108,109]. Modification and structural design based on such materials are the most common methods for improving the performance of sulfur cathodes. Cui et al. [110] systematically investigated the yolk-shell nanostructure of TiO2-coated sulfur and the detailed synthesis method is depicted in Fig. 5 (a). Such unique sulfur–TiO2 core–shell nanostructures significantly prolong the cycle performance. In addition, the average Coulomb efficiency is 98.4%, which is ascribed to the nanostructure that adapts the volume expansion of blank space, TiO2 shell with a complete mesoporous structure, and polysulfide anion combination of hydrophilic Ti-O groups. These factors hamper the dissolution of sulfide. The similar yolk-shell structure of MnO2-coated sulfur resulted in cathodes with a very low fading rate of 0.039% per cycle over 1700 cycles in LSBs [111]. The catalytic effect of metal oxides has played a positive role in the development of LSBs. An efficient catalytic system can accelerate the liquid–solid transition in LSBs and reduce the shuttle effect caused by concentration gradient. Zhang et al. [27] prepared a Mn3O4− x catalyst by a two-step method to selectively catalyze the internal redox reaction of LSBs, inhibit the shuttle effect of polysulfides, and endow LSBs with excellent electrochemical stability. The catalytic mechanism and intermediate reaction barrier change process during the charge and discharge process were explored by in-situ XRD diagram and theoretical calculation. The formation of MnS and Li y Mn z O4− x intermediate products reduces the conversion energy barrier of Li2S4 to Li2S2/Li2S during the reaction process, as indicated by in-situ XRD. Specifically, soluble LiPSs are typically adsorbed on the surface of Mn3O4− x catalyst via Mn-S bonds, whereas insoluble LiPSs are typically adsorbed via Li-O bonds. Mn3O4− x can, therefore, directly reshape the Ea and active sites of Li2S n using MnS and Li y Mn z O4− x as intermediates during the sulfur reduction reaction, thereby accelerating the heterogeneous transformation reaction. Therefore, the Mn3O4− x catalyst decreased the energy barrier of liquid-to-solid conversion, promoted the conversion of liquid Li2S4 to solid Li2S2, effectively resolved the problem of liquid–solid conversion difficulty in LSB, and substantially reduced the shuttle effect caused by the accumulation of liquid LiPSs during dynamic conversion. In addition, since Mn3O4- x was produced by introducing oxygen vacancies on the (103) crystal surface of Mn3O4− x to control its surface charge, DFT calculations reveal their distinct roles in electrochemical reactions. The outcomes demonstrate electron transfer between Mn and S and Li and O atoms. Due to the presence of oxygen vacancies, however, adjacent Mn atoms are more likely to react with S atoms, so the adsorption energy of Li2S6 on Mn3O4− x is slightly greater than that of Mn3O4− x . In addition, the introduction of oxygen vacancy has effectively improved the d-band center of the Mn3O4− x catalyst, which can better match the frontier molecular orbital of Li2S4 and has a greater affinity for liquid–solid conversion of LSBs. Thus, compared to Mn3O4, Mn3O4− x catalyst has a greater adsorption capacity for liquid polysulfide and can selectively accelerate the liquid-to-solid conversion within the LSB, effectively inhibit the shuttle effect of polysulfide, and protect the lithium anode. In addition, the Mn3O4− x catalyst has a high affinity for Li2S, allowing it to effectively regulate the deposition and reactivation of Li2S and preserve the durability of LSB. Thus, the designed LSB based on Mn3O4− x catalyst achieved an extremely long cycle life of 2000 cycles and an extremely low capacity decay rate of 0.028 % per cycle at 2.5C. Compared with metal oxides, metal sulfides as sulfur cathode hosts have the advantages of effectively anchoring polysulfides and catalyzing their conversion, as well as having an improved conductivity. In addition, some even exhibit half-metallic or metal properties [112,113]. Considering the sulfur-philic effect of CoS2, Zhang et al. [114] doped CoS2 into carbon/sulfur cathodes, which resulted in a strong interaction between lithium polysulfide and CoS2. As shown in Fig. 5(b), the interface formed between CoS2 and the electrolyte served as a site where polar polysulfides were strongly adsorbed and activated to accelerate the redox reaction of polysulfides. The high reactivity of polysulfide not only guarantees the effective inhibition of polarization and a 10% increase in energy efficiency but also provides a high discharge capacity and stable cycle performance over 2000 cycles. The results demonstrated that the capacity attenuation rate was 0.034% per cycle at 2 C and the initial capacity was 1368 mA h g−1 at 0.5 C. With the participation of CoS2, the discharge capacity of the composite material containing 75 wt% sulfur increased by approximately 60%, the energy efficiency increased by approximately 10%, and the capacity attenuation rate was 0.034% per cycle within 2000 cycles at a 0.2 C rate. Nazar et al. [115] reported a metal material of Co9S8 with an interconnected graphene-like nanostructure. The results of first-principles calculations and spectral data indicated that the polysulfide has a synergistic strong dual interaction with the host. Compared with the standard porous carbon, the 3D interconnection structure with hierarchical pores not only enhanced the cyclic stability by ten times (the capacity attenuation rate was 0.045% per cycle after 1500 cycles at 0.5 C) but, more importantly, the sulfur-content of the sulfur electrode reached 75 wt%, and the surface loading was 4.5 mg cm−2. As an important member of multi-component metal chalcogenides, Cu–Bi–S alloys are composed of 13 compounds with different stoichiometric ratios of these three elements. They are stable at room temperature and are composed of earth-abundant and low-cost elements, such as Bi and S [116]. Therefore, Cu–Bi–S compounds have received attracted considerable attention as a sulfur host material for LSBs. Gao et al. [117] synthesized flower-like Cu3BiS3 using a solvent heat method (Fig. 5c). The typical flower-like porous structure of Cu3BiS3 could effectively load sulfur particles and trap polysulfides, providing a good reaction kinetics, so that the as-prepared Cu3BiS3/S compositeaccommodated 80 wt% sulfur and showcased an initial discharge capacity of 1343 mA h g−1 at 0.2C. Despite the capacity attenuation caused by the dissolution of polysulfide and shuttle effect in subsequent cycles, the residual capacity still reached 487 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles and the Coulomb efficiency was 90%–95%. Similar multi-metal sulfides used as cathodes for LSBs include NiCo2S4 and ZnCo2S4. Li etal. [118] prepared self-assembled NiCo2S4 granules with secondary open-hole tubular structures as sulfur hosts. Thermogravimetric analysis revealed that the sulfur content of the NiCo2S4/S composite is 67 wt%. Sulfiphilic NiCo2S4 nanotubes hosts have large porosity, high conductivity, fast ion conduction, strong polysulfide immobilization ability and catalytic effect on polysulfide redox, which greatly improved the polysulfide shuttle problem and accelerated the polysulfide conversion kinetics. With a high sulfur-loading of 8.9 mg cm−2, the NiCo2S4/S cathode delivered a high initial capacity of 1387 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C and retained 816 mA h g−1 after 350 cycles. The ZnCo2S4 prepared by Zhang etal. [119] was derived from the metal–organic foam. As a sulfur host, it can form polar bonds with soluble polysulfides and improve the binding force to inhibit the shuttle effect. The ZnCo2S4 grown on the conductive carbon cloth promotes rapid electron transfer, and its hierarchical structure adapts to the volume expansion of sulfur in LSBs. In addition, ZnCo2S4 has a smaller Li ion diffusion barrier energy than ZnCo2S4. As a result, the ZnCo2S4/S exhibited an initial capacity of 1146 mA h g−1 and a capacity of 531 mA h g−1 at 0.5 C after cycling 200 times, which is superior to that of ZnCo2O4/S. In addition, multi-metal oxides, such as ZnCo2O4 [120], NiCo2O4 [121,122], BaTiO3 [123], LiNi x Co y Mn1− x − y O2 [124], and Mg0.6Ni0.4O [125], and multi-metal selenides, such as NiCo2Se4 [126], are also promising host materials for long-cycle and high-capacity LSBs. Most of the transition metal oxides have poor conductivity but good chemical stability and have good affinities for lithium polysulfide, while metal sulfides, nitrides and phosphides, experience the opposite. Therefore, the advantages of oxides and sulfides or phosphides can be combined via doping to improve the catalyst properties, thereby improving the kinetics of the lithium–sulfur catalytic conversion. Among them, oxygen-doped materials can improve the affinity of the catalyst to LiPSs owing to the strong Li-O interactions. Wu et al. [127] studied oxygen-doped methods and materials with high concentrations of oxygen. High-density oxygen-doped NiCo2S4 (NiCo2(OS)4) can easily be obtained by controlling the degree of sulfidation (Fig. 5d). The morphology of NiCo2(OS)4 is flower-like, and the crystal structure is similar to that of cubic NiCo2S4. However, the O:S atomic ratio can exceed 1.5:1. This material not only inherits the high conductivity of NiCo2S4 but also maintains the stability of NiCo2O4 in air. In addition, it is superior to NiCo2O4 and NiCo2S4 in adsorbing LiPSs and catalyzing LiPSs conversion. The as-fabricated NiCo2(OS)4 paper-supported Li–S cell achieved a high capacity of 962 mA h g−1 (2.8 mA h cm−2) at 0.2 C after 200 cycles and 922 mA h g−1 (2.7 mA h cm−2) at 0.5C after 150 cycles. 3.4.2 Metal borides, nitrides, and phosphides The rational design of sulfur host materials with catalytic functions has become an effective strategy to promote polysulfide conversion. Recent studies have concluded that transition metal borides with high conductivity and catalytic ability are more suitable as sulfur host materials than other types of transition metal compounds. Xu et al. [128] used metallic and polar TiB2 nanomaterials as sulfur hosts. Through experimental analysis and density functional theory (DFT) theoretical calculations, they proposed that S8 molecules were decomposed into sulfur atoms on the surface of TiB2 to form a sulfur-sulfonated surface. This surface can allow S8 molecules to be stably adsorbed onto the surface of TiB2. Note that TiB2 strongly bonds to polysulfides, effectively inhibiting the shuttle effect (Fig. 5e). As a result, with a high sulfur-content of 70%, the 70S/TiB2cathode achieved a high capacity of 842 mA h g−1 after 150 cycles at 0.2 C and the average capacity fading per cycle was 0.058% after 500 cycles at 1 C (Fig. 5f). Recently, they [129] tested the performance of NbB2 as a sulfur host. By using the classical melt diffusion pattern, they synthesized a NbB2/nitrogen-phosphorus co-doped graphene/sulfur (NbB2/NPG/S) composite. The as-obtained cathode showcased stable capacities of 1014 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.2 C and could stably operate at 10 C for over 1300 cycles (Fig. 5g). Nazar et al. [130] proposed the use of a lightweight superconducting material MgB2 as a sulfur-loading conductor. DFT calculations show that MgB2 exhibits a different polysulfide adsorption mechanism from metal oxides because both Mg and B atoms on the surface directly bond with polysulfide anions (S x 2−) rather than Li+. This chemical action mechanism, coupled with the conductivity of MgB2, directly transfers the interface charge to the polysulfide ions that are involved in the redox reaction without interference from Li+. It is a feasible method to improve the electrochemical performance by combining polar metal compounds with conductive carbon materials to form composite materials, which synergistically play the role of anchoring and catalytic converting LiPSs. Zhao et al. [131] designed a CG network structure of 1D CNTs interspersed with 2D graphene, which was loaded with a heterostructured CoP-Co2N@N-doped carbon polyhedron to form a 3D CoP-Co2N@NC/CG composite. The CoP-Co2N heterostructure is responsible for the chemical adsorption of LiPSs and its catalytic conversion to short-chain lithium sulfide. The nitrogen-doped carbon layer (NC) in the outer layer of CoP–Co2N acts as a second barrier to restrict the diffusion of Li2S n molecules and provides an effective way for rapid Li+/e− transport. The CG network not only supports CoP–Co2N@NC to prevent detachment from the electrode during cycling but also forms a long-range conductive network. The sulfur content in the obtained composite cathode is 73.3%. After 500 cycles at 2 C, it maintained a high specific capacity of 988 mA h g−1 with a high Coulombic efficiency that exceeded 99%. 3.4.3 Mxenes (metal carbides and nitrides) MXenes are a new type of 2D transition metal carbides, nitrides, and carbonitrides discovered. Owing to their unique 2D structure, high conductivity, and redundant surface redundant, they have attracted considerable attention because of their energy storage and conversion capabilities [132,133]. As shown in Fig. 6 , MXene-based materials have been applied in cathodes, separators, and anodes of LSBs [134,135]. Metallic carbides can adsorb and catalyze LiPSs at electrode active sites and can improve the cycle stability and rate performance of LSBs [136]. Liang et al. [137] reported a 2D MXene sulfur host material Ti2C. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis revealed that Ti2C can effectively adsorb LiPSs and form S–Ti–C bonds between sulfur and the edge metallic sites. The composite cathode still has a very stable cycle performance and high capacity with a sulfur content of 70%. The initial discharge capacity of the Ti2C/S composite is 1090 mA h g−1 at 0.5 C and remains at 723 mA h g−1 after 650 cycles. Huang et al. [138] designed the dual-chemisorption Ti3C2/S@PDA cathode consisting of an MXene matrix backbone that is overcoated by a porous polydopamine (PDA) layer. MXene forms a strong Ti–S bond via the Lewis acid–base interaction with Li2S x , while PDA captures Li2S x flow through polar–polar interactions. Therefore, the dual-chemisorption cathode achieved an initial capacity of 1001 mA h g−1 at a high sulfur-loading of 5 mg cm−2 and a very low-capacity fading rate of 0.035% per cycle over 1000 cycles at 0.2 C. This design concept of double-adsorption can be extended to the composite materials of MXenes and other materials with polar sites, such as TiO2 [139], MnO2 [140], MoS2 [141,142], and functionalized CNTs [143]. The detailed synthesis of these composites is shown in Fig. 7 , mainly including polymer coating, oxide loading, freeze-drying, annealing, hydrothermal, and self-assembly. To solve the problems of the shuttle effect and poor reaction kinetics of LSBs, Hu et al. [144] used a magnolol monomer as a nucleophile to modify the surface chemical properties of Ti3C2T x , reduce the F terminal group, generate more CTiO functional groups with strong adsorption and catalytic conversion, and increase the number of double bond functional groups on the surface of Ti3C2T x , which can polymerize with sulfur and play the role of covalent bonding sulfur fixation. Therefore, MTi3C2T x S was used as the cathode of an LSB that exhibited good electrochemical performance. The reversible capacity reached 640.7 mA h g−1 after 900 cycles at 0.5 C, and the average capacity decay rate per cycle was only 0.041%. Under the conditions of a higher sulfur-loading (7.2 mg cm−2) and lower electrolyte/sulfur ratio (8.2 μL mg−1), the area specific capacity was 7.68 mA h cm−2 and the capacity decay rate per cycle was 0.07% after 150 cycles at 0.1 C. This flexible MXene surface modification strategy is expected to be extended to other diverse MXene-based LSB applications. 3.4.4 Metal–organic frameworks Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of porous coordination compound materials with regular pores formed by metal centers or clusters as nodes that coordinate with carboxylic acid or nitrogen-containing organic multidentate ligands [145,146]. The diversity of their structures and functions, selectable particle size, high porosity, large specific surface area, and Lewis acid–base interactions between their metal sites and polysulfides make MOFs, MOF composites, and MOF-derived materials highly suitable as cathode skeleton materials for LSBs that can effectively alleviate the dissolution of LiPSs and accelerate the conversion of LiPSs [147–149]. In 2011, Demir-Cakan et al. [150] discovered that when mesoporous chromium-based MOFs are used as the sulfur skeleton in LSB cathodes, the capacity retention of the cathode is significantly improved. Afterwards, researchers combined various MOF materials with active sulfur and studied the electrochemical performance of the composite cathodes. Wang et al. [151] compounded a highly porous open-framework metal coordination polymer [Cu3(TMA)2(H2O)3] n (HKUST-1) with elemental sulfur by direct grinding. The mass fraction of sulfur in the obtained composite HKUST-1/S is 40%, and the composite HKUST-1 ⊃ S is obtained after treating HKUST-1/S at a high temperature of 155 °C for 24 h. HKUST-1/S and HKUST-1⊃S were prepared as cathode materials of LSBs. Testing at the charge rate of 0.1 C and discharge rate of 0.05 C, HKUST-1/S and HKUST-1⊃S exhibited excellent initial discharge capacities of 1507 and 1498 mA h g−1, respectively. The discharge specific capacity of HKUST-1/S decreased to 350 mA h g−1 after 50 cycles. The electrochemical performance of HKUST-1/S remained excellent, and it retained a discharge specific capacity of 500 mA h g−1 after 170 cycles. To increase the sulfur-content, Xiao et al. [152] constructed a Ni-based MOF (Ni-MOF) with interwoven mesopores and micropores (Fig. 8 a). With a high specific surface area of 5243 m2 g−1 (Fig. 8b), the hierarchical porous structured Ni-MOF was loaded with 60 wt% sulfur. The mesopores and micropores inhibit the migration of polysulfides and accelerate the transfer of electrons and ions, which effectively improves the cycle performance of the battery. Concurrently, the interaction between the Ni2+ (Lewis acid) in the MOFs and S x 2− (Lewis base) in the polysulfides can reduce polysulfide dissolution. Under these synergistic effects, the specific capacity retention rate of the as-prepared Ni-MOFs/S composites after 200 cycles at 0.1 C is approximately 75%. Most MOFs have poor conductivity, which is not conducive to the redox reaction, resulting in a low specific capacity of the battery. Designing and synthesizing conductive MOFs constructed with extended π-conjugated ligands or graphene-like structures has become an effective strategy to solve this problem [153–157]. Cai et al. [158] synthesized a highly conductive MOF, namely Ni3(HITP)2, where HITP is 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaiminotriphenylene (Fig. 8c), using a hydrothermal method. Ni3(HITP)2 has a 2D layered structure, similar to that of graphene, with an electrical conductivity of up to 4000 S m−1. Thus, it is superior to most coordination polymers. The obtained S@Ni3(HITP)2can load up to 65.5 wt% sulfur. Furthermore, CNTs were used as conductive additives to improve rate the capability and electrochemical durability. The high conductivity, porosity, and polysulfide chemical adsorption of this conductive-MOF-based sulfur cathode endow the LSBs assembled using this material with good rate and cycle performances. Notably, the as-prepared S@Ni3(HITP)2-CNT composite showcased an initial discharge specific capacity of 1302.9 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C and reserved 848.9 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles. Moreover, after 150 and 300 cycles at 0.5 and 1 C, the reversible discharge capacities of the S@Ni3(HITP)2 were maintained at 807.4 and 629.6 mA h g−1, respectively. To improve the performance of MOF-based sulfur cathodes, researchers have compounded MOFs with conductive carbon materials and conductive polymers to prepare composite materials as the cathode skeleton of LSBs. Recently, Cao et al. [159] designed a Ni-HHTP, where HHTP is 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexahydroxytriphenylene, to decorate self-supported carbon paper to adsorb and reduce polysulfides (Fig. 8d). Benefiting from the excellent conductivity, strong chemical adsorption toward polysulfides, and interface engineering of Ni-HHTP, the designed Ni-HHTP-modified carbon paper cathode has an excellent cycling performance with a retained capacity of 910 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.2 C, which corresponds to a decay rate as low as 0.165% per cycle. A high rate performance of 892 mA h g−1 at 2 C rate was also achieved. Qiu et al. [160] developed a ZIF/CNFs composite interlayer of electrospun CNFs decorated by in-situ grown cobalt-based MOFs (ZIF-67), which can inhibit the dissolution of polysulfides and reduce the shuttle effect by synergistic physical blocking and chemical capturing (Fig. 8e). Concurrently, the 3D CNF fiber network provides an interconnected conductive framework between the ZIF microreactors, which promotes rapid electron transfer during cycling, thereby contributing to excellent rates and cycle performances. Hence, an LSB with an ZIF/CNF interlayer showed a high specific capacity of 1334 mA h g−1 at 1 C and exhibited an excellent cycle stability over 300 cycles. This electrospinning and co-precipitation fabrication method provides a scalable and affordable strategy for the design of MOF-derived carbon materials for high-performance LSBs. Liu et al. [161] synthesized CNT@UIO66-NH2 using a solvothermal method. Then, thiol groups (SH) were introduced into CNT@UIO66 by the condensation of thioacetic acid with the amide group in CNT@UIO66-NH2. Finally, CNT@UIO66-S was prepared by the covalent connection of sulfur with CNT@UIO66-SH, as shown in Fig. 8(f). The covalent bond between CNT@UIO66-SH and sulfur prevented the composite material from producing free polysulfides during the discharge process. Therefore, the shuttle effect was suppressed. Additionally, CNTs improved the conductivity of the electrode. The synergistic effect of these two methods enables the discharge capacity of the battery to reach 416 mA h g−1 at 2 C after 900 cycles (Fig. 8g). Deng et al. [162] significantly improved the conductivity of MOFs based on the three criteria for the electrode active materials of high-performance LSBs, namely polarity, porosity, and conductivity (Fig. 8i). Good conductivity is the basis of electrochemical fast reaction kinetics of LSBs, and it is also a necessary condition for high-rate charge and discharge. High porosity is the guarantee of high sulfur content and rapid ion diffusion, and porosity and polarity can effectively confine LiPSs in the pores, inhibit their dissolution, and promote their transformation. They selected three MOFs with different pore structures and prepared the PPy-S-in-MOF materials by the three-step process shown in Fig. 8(h). After PPy encapsulation, the conductivity of the PPy-S-in-MOFs were significantly increased by 105–107 orders of magnitude compared to pristine MOFs. This provides the possibility for high-rate charging and discharging of composite materials. In addition, shorter ion diffusion paths and larger pores in MOFs can improve the ion transfer efficiency. Among them, PPy-S-in-PCN-224 with cross-linked pores and tunnels has the best capacity retention performance (Fig. 8j). Even at 10 C, the battery with PPy-S-in-PCN-224 as the cathode still has high capacities of 640 mA h g−1 after 400 cycles and 440 mA h g−1 after 1000 cycles (Fig. 8k). These PPy-MOF structures represent a new way to solve the conductivity problem of MOFs so their geometric advantages can be fully utilized. This research also sets an example for the application of non-conductive MOFs in electrochemical applications. In the development of these metal-compound sulfur host materials, researchers have extensively employed the anchoring and catalytic conversion ability of metal-based compounds with regard to sulfur to overcome the shuttle effect of LSBs and increase the sulfur content in the cathodes. In addition, the dissolution of polysulfides and volume expansion of the electrode have been further limited by structural design. However, despite these improvements, there is still substantial room for further enhancement for the commercial application of LSBs. For example, a clear understanding of the restriction and catalytic conversion mechanisms of polysulfides on metal compounds is crucial for improving the sulfur utilization and inhibiting the shuttle effect. In addition to the study of the conversion of soluble polysulfides, the rapid conversion of insoluble Li2S2, which plays an important role in the improvement of the reversible capacity, should also be studied further [109]. The possible phase transition of metal compound catalysts during electrochemical cycling has an important influence on the physical and chemical properties of sulfur hosts and can also significantly change the electrochemical performance of sulfur cathodes. In addition, the adsorption energy effect, conductivity, diffusion rate of Li+, and coordination of unsaturated atoms of LiPSs should considered as important indicators for structure and morphology control [163]. Furthermore, the selection of low-cost materials and structural design with low technical thresholds are more suitable for practical applications. Non-noble metal compounds with natural abundance and bionic natural structures can be considered for this purpose. These perspectives facilitate the design and manufacture of cheap, efficient, and safe LSBs with high energy densities. 3.5 Polymers Polymers have become promising materials for fixing elemental sulfur and inhibiting polysulfide dissolution on account of their structural designability, versatility, excellent chemical stability, and processability [164,165]. Polymer-based sulfur host materials mainly include polysulfide trapping polymers [164] and electrochemically active sulfur-containing polymers (organic sulfur polymers) [166,167]. Polysulfide trapping polymers are mainly classified as conductive and non-conductive polymers according to their conductivity. 3.5.1 Polysulfide trapping polymers 3.5.1.1 Non-conductive polymers Although non-conductive polymers cannot improve the conductivity of the sulfur cathode, polymers with polar groups or side chains have great potential in reducing the shuttle effect of lithium polysulfides. Common polymers, such as PAN [168], PVP [45,169], polyethylene glycol [170], polyacrylamide [171], polyimide [172], and PDA [173], and even less common ones, such as polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) [174], poly(acrylic acid) [175,176], and poly(ethylene oxide) [69,177], which are often used as binders, are also high-performance sulfur host materials with functional groups that can reduce the shuttle effect. Typical examples are shown in Fig. 9 . Cui et al. [178] synthesized monodisperse PVP nanospheres to encapsulate sulfur and introduced an empty space between elemental sulfur and PVP to minimize the polysulfide dissolution, reduce volume expansion, facilitate electron and ion transport, and facilitate more uniform mixing of sulfur in the electrode and intimate contact with conductive additives. A clear schematic of the formation mechanism for PVP-encapsulated hollow sulfur nanospheres is shown in Fig. 9(a), which resulted in a 70.4 wt% sulfur content in the PVP-S composites. This monodisperse polymer-coated hollow sulfur cathode delivered a high capacity of 1179 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C. Moreover, this composite cathode possesses an excellent cycling performance over 1000 cycles and the residual capacity is 73.4% after 500 cycles at 0.5 C. Composites composed of polymers and conductive materials and prepared from specialized designs are common for obtaining high-performance cathode materials for LSBs. Huang et al. [179] constructed a binder-free Janus separator by in-situ interfacial polymerization of an ultrathin covalent triazine piperazine (CTP) membrane containing customizable micropores and adsorption sites on electrospun PAN membranes, creating a triple barrier for LiPSs. That is, the strong polar nitrile groups in PAN and lithiophilic sites in CTP achieve effective double effect adsorption of LiPSs. In addition, the steric hindrance effect of the micro mesoporous structure acts as a barrier of LiPSs, as shown in Fig. 9(b). The combination of steric hindrance and chemisorption reduced the migration of LiPSs by 81.85 %. At the same time, a fast ion conductor Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 (LLZTO) was formed on the surface of the PAN nanofibers by magnetron sputtering at the anode interface, creating a mutually embedded structure to inhibit dendrite growth and overcome powder-stripping during cycling. The Li-S cell with a CTP-PAN-LLZTO separator exhibited excellent electrochemical performance, providing an initial discharge specific capacity of 1287.9 mA h g−1 at 0.5 C and maintaining a capacity of 905.5 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles, which is 3.1 times higher than that of commercial polypropylene separators. A good rate performance of 547.3 mA h g−1 at 5C also indicates its ability to charge and discharge quickly. The design concept of this bifunctional Janus separator has been widely used in the preparation and modification of multi-functional separators for LSBs, paving the way for LSBs with long-term cyclic stability. The CTP mentioned above is a COF material. COFs are a special kind of porous material [180] and their structures and properties are highly customizable. This is because they can have 3D or 2D structures. In addition, they can be either non-conductive or conductive [181,182]. Therefore, the cathode modification of LSBs has also attracted much attention [48,183,184]. As shown in Fig. 10 (a–c), selecting appropriate linking groups, such as triazines, boroxines, imides, and cationic quaternary ammoniums, can enhance the interaction between sulfur species and heterogeneous components, thereby facilitating the chemical anchoring to LiPS [185]. Among them, borooxy- and imide-linked COF/S cathodes had initial capacities that exceeded 1600 mA h g−1, which is close to the theoretical capacity of LSBs. Both COF-based sulfur cathodes have a long-term stability at high current density of 0.5 C [186,187]. Recently, Zhang and Gu et al. [188] synthesized an allyl-rich triazine COF (ART-COF) containing both triazines and allyls through molecular structure design. As shown in Fig. 10(d), the synergistic effect of Li+-N dipole–dipole interactions and CS covalent binding effectively inhibited LiPS shuttling. Compared with AFT-COFs without allyl groups or containing only allyl group without triazine structures as sulfur cathode materials, ART-COF significantly improves the cycle stability of LSBs. As shown in Fig. 10(e, f), under the condition of 62 wt% sulfur-content, the initial capacity of the ART-COF/S composite cathode is 1270 mA h g−1 and a reversible capacity of 1220 mA h g−1can be maintained after 100 cycles at 0.2 C. Even at a high current density of 1 C, the initial capacity is 993 mA h g−1, which remains at 818 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles. This study is a classic example of using synergistic effects to rationally design COF materials to improve their performance, which helps to develop practical LSBs with high capacities, high rate performances, and long cycle lives. 3.5.1.2 Conductive polymers Conductive polymers (CPs) have unique electrical properties similar to those of inorganic semiconductors and metals and can be synthesized by facile, versatile, and cost-effective methods. The non-localized π-electron conjugated system and numerous surface polar functional groups in their main chain can effectively adsorb polysulfides as active centers. In addition, they have the advantage of a high conductivity that can improve the rate performance of sulfur cathodes [189]. At the same time, the special dendritic and porous structure of CPs can prevent sulfur agglomeration and alleviate the problem of sulfur volume expansion in LSBs [112]. To date, many conductive polymers, such as polythiophene (PTh), poly (3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT), polyaniline (PANI), PPy, and pyrolyzed PAN (pPAN), have been reported as promising sulfur carriers. However, the sulfur-content and electrochemical performances of these conductive polymer/sulfur composites are relatively low [23]. For example, PTh-S core–shell structures and PTh lamella-wrapped sulfur composites can achieve initial discharge capacities of over 1000 mA h g−1 at 0.1C but their residual capacities are lower than 70% after 80 or 90 cycles [190,191]. Liu and Cao et al. [192] synthesized a self-assembled vulcanized polyaniline (SPANI)/NT composite material by in-situ vulcanization at 280 °C, which exhibited a capacity of 837 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.1 C under a 62 wt% sulfur content. It is worth noting that based on the previous design of polymer-coated hollow sulfur nanospheres, Cui et al. [193] used conductive polymers, namely PPy, PANI, and PEDOT, as the surface coating of monodisperse hollow sulfur nanospheres to synthesize core–shell-structured PPy-S, PANI-S, and PEDOT-S composite electrodes with high sulfur-contents of 77, 74, and 78 wt%, respectively, and high electrochemical performance. Theoretical calculations show that PEDOT has a much stronger binding energy with the lithium atom in Li x S (0 < x ≤ 2) than PANI and PPy. Meanwhile, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy showed that the order of conductivity reduction was PEDOT > PPy > PANI. Therefore, the ability of three CP-coated sulfur composites to achieve long cycle lives and high rate performances is PEDOT-S > PPy-S > PAN-S. After 500 cycles at a 0.5C rate, the PEDOT-S and PPy-S cathodes exhibited high reversible capacities of 780 and 726 mA h g−1, respectively. Even at 4C, PEDOT-S, PPy-S, and PANI-S delivered capacities of 624, 440, and 329 mA h g−1, respectively. To realize rechargeable LSBs with a high sulfur-loading, high energy densities, long cycle lives, and excellent rate capabilities, Chen et al.
