[194] synthesized multi compartment micro/mesoporous carbon nanocube-encapsulated sulfur coated by homogeneous PEDOT (P@CNC-S) composites using the double constraint strategy, as shown in Fig. 11 (a and b). The P@CNC-S nanocomposites had a sulfur content of 72% and exhibited a superior initial capacity of 1086 mA h g−1 at 1 C, which stabilized at 927 mA h g−1 after 1000 cycles (Fig. 11c). The electrochemical performance of P@CNC-S nanocomposites is far superior to that of CNC-S nanocomposites, which is mainly ascribed to the enhanced conductivity originating from the introduced PEDOT. Guo et al. [195] designed and synthesized 3D-structured polypyrrole@sulfur@graphene aerogels (PPy@S@GA) by vapor phase polymerization of pyrrole monomers on the surface of the S@GA aerogels, as shown in Fig. 11(d). The physical confinement of the porosity structure together with the chemical adsorption of the PPy-coated layer effectively reduced the shuttle effect of LiPSs, endowing the PPy@S@GA 3D cathode with a high capacity of 741 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles at 0.5 C, which corresponds a capacity fading of 0.031% per cycle (Fig. 11e). pPAN is produced by the pyrolysis of PAN. It has a high conductivity (up to 100 S cm−1), oxygen stability, high charge storage capacity, and broad application prospects in electrochemistry [196–198]. Wang et al. [199] synthesized pyrolyzed composites of PAN-Ketjenblack carbon and sulfur (pPAN-KB/S) through a high throughput aerosol-assisted process (Fig. 11f). As a cathode material, sulfur was trapped both by the physisorption KB carbon and the chemical bonding of pPAN. Therefore, with high sulfur-content of 72%, the pPAN-KB/S electrode achieved high capacity and excellent rate performance at high current density, which are superior to that of KB/S. The pPAN-KB/S composite preserved a high capacity of 856 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.5 C and the rate capacity at 5 C was 431 mA h g−1 (Fig. 11g and h). Even with a high areal sulfur-loading of 4.4 mg S cm− 2, the pPAN-KB/S composite delivered extremely high gravimetric and volumetric capacities of 513 mA h g−1 and 576 mA h cm−3, respectively, after 100 cycles at a 0.5 C. 3.5.2 Electrochemically active sulfur-containing polymers In the process of anchoring sulfur by the various physical methods such as coating, impregnation, and nanoscale limitation, many researchers have also used chemical bonding to fix sulfur and LiPSs. Electrochemically active sulfur-containing polymers are a class of polymers that specifically improve the performance of LSBs by chemical bonds. These sulfur-containing polymers are divided into vulcanized polymer, including vulcanized conductive polymers and vulcanized rubbers, and inverse vulcanization copolymers, including sulfur-unsaturated hydrocarbon copolymers, sulfur-benzoxazine copolymers, sulfur-thiol copolymers, sulfur-CTF copolymers, and sulfur copolymers with conductive polymers, which are discussed in our previous review [166]. (1) Vulcanized polymers Vulcanized polymers have a long history starting in the late 1990s. The emphasis on polymers in LSBs began in the study of vulcanized conductive polymers as cathode active materials for LSBs. With the deepening of the structural design and optimization of polysulfide polymers with conductive polymer backbones by Yang et al. [200], they determined that carbyne polysulfide has a high theoretical specific capacity of 1058 mA h g−1. In 2013 and 2017, they synthesized a carbyne polysulfide with S m (1 ≤ m ≤ 4) bonding to the carbon skeleton and a nitrogen-doped carbyne polysulfide (N-CAS), respectively (Fig. 12 a and b) [201,202]. The electronic conductivity of the former is 2.5 × 10−4 S cm−1, whereas that of the latter is 5.6 × 10−4 S cm−1. After 200 cycles at 0.1 C, the carbyne polysulfide exhibits a high reversible capacity of 960 mA h g−1. Under nitrogen doping, the conjugated structure formed on the N-CAS skeleton can adsorb lithium ions and electrons through a lithium-coupled electron transfer process, so that it delivered an initial capacity of up to 1570 mA h g−1 at a current density of 200 mA g−1 and maintained capacities of 1003 and 900 mA h g−1 after the 100th and 300th cycles, respectively. However, the sulfur content of these two conductive polymers are only 54.1 and 40.3 wt%, which considerably lower than the energy density advantage of LSBs. To increase the sulfur-content, Zhao et al. [203] developed a sulfur-rich carbon polysulfide polymer with 3.0 wt% graphene (CS x ) n -G-380 by the simultaneous polymerization reaction of hexachlorobutadiene and substitution of polysulfide at 380 °C (Fig. 12c). The resulting composite has a sulfur content of up to 90 wt% and exhibits an initial capacity of 999 mA h g−1 at a current density of 200 mA g−1 based on the mass of the (CS x ) n -G-380, which remains 550 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles. Thus, it is difficult to balance the high sulfur-content and capacity retention of vulcanized conductive polymers. It is an effective method to obtain vulcanized conductive polymers with a high sulfur-loading, specific capacity, and rate performance by directly sulfurizing the modified conductive polymers and processing them into hierarchical nanoporous structures. Yan et al. [204] prepared hierarchical coralloid-like structured SPANI using a facile chemical hot reflux approach that affords a high sulfur content of 65 wt% and excellent electric/ionic conductivity (Fig. 12d). Polyaniline molecular chains are connected by the disulfide bonds and the elemental sulfur is confined between the molecular chains. The porous structure further enhances fast ionic conduction and mass transport. In addition, it also enhances the interface contact between the polar discharge polysulfide species and non-polar carbon. As a result, the SPANI electrode showcased an initial discharge capacity of 937 mA h g−1 at 0.3 C, which corresponded to a high sulfur utilization rate of 58.2%. After 200 cycles, a stable reversible capacity of 734 mA h g−1 was preserved with a low decay rate of 0.051% per cycle (Fig. 12e). Meanwhile, the Coulombic efficiency was maintained at 99.3% (Fig. 12f), indicating that the multi-shuttle effect in the battery was significantly reduced. Even at 2C, the SPANI electrode maintained a capacity of more than 700 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles, indicating that the SPANI cathode played a key role in extending the high rate cycle life of LSBs. Sulfided PAN (SPAN) is also a conductive vulcanized polymer with excellent electrochemical performance [205]. However, only when the sulfur content in SPAN is less than 40% will the SPAN electrode exhibit an excellent capacity retention (95–100%) and high discharge capacity (based on the mass of sulfur). However, because of the low sulfur mass, the discharge capacity calculated based on the SPAN mass was generally lower than 500 mA h g−1, which is insufficient for the use of LSBs in practical applications. Recently, Yan et al. [206] determined that when the sulfide bonds were installed on the polymer side chain, as shown in Fig. 12(g), the main chain would not break when the sulfide bonds broke apart, which greatly reduced the probability of dissolution and diffusion of the intermediate product. Theoretical calculation and experimental characterization show that the free radicals generated by the homolytic cleavage of the SS bond in poly (diallyl tetrasulfide) (PDATtS) react with Li+ to form thiolate (RSLi) and insoluble Li2S or Li2S2 (Fig. 12h and i). Therefore, the problem of rapid capacity decline caused by the formation of soluble polysulfide intermediates and its serious shuttle effect in traditional LSBs is completely avoided and a dendrite-free LSB is realized. Therefore, when PDATtS is used as a cathode active material, it can provide a high capacity of 700 mA h g−1 even at loadings as high as 10.3 mg cm−2 and maintain a stable capacity of 85% after 300 cycles. The high area capacity of the electrode is approximately 4 mA h cm−2, which is sufficient to make the energy density of the cathode larger than that of existing LIBs. The use of vulcanized rubber as cathode active materials was first reported by Han et al. [207] in 2014. Commercially available low-cost linear polymer polysulfide rubber was used as a raw material to obtain a sulfur-rich polymer with a sulfur content of up to 89 wt% by simple vulcanization. As a cathode active material for LSBs, the as-prepared sulfur-rich polymer showed an initial specific capacity of 675 mA h g−1 at a current density of 1 mA cm−2, stabilized at nearly 586 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles, and had a capacity retention rate of 87%. Yu et al. [208] prepared a CNF/R/S electrode with a sulfur content of 85 wt% by extracting vulcanized polymers from waste tires or rubber stoppers and compounding them with elemental sulfur to prepare a high sulfur content composite, followed by coating the composite on CNF films using a solution dropping method (Fig. 12j). During the charge and discharge processes of the CNF/R/S electrode, in addition to the normal reaction between lithium and sulfur, the reaction between lithium and the CS bond also occurs. Thus, the CS bond disappears during the discharge process to form CLi bonds and the CLi bond disappears during the charge process, while the CS bond is reformed. Therefore, under the action of multiple mechanisms, the reversible capacity of the CNF/R/S electrode exceeds 800 mA h g−1 at 1 C after 200 cycles (Fig. 12k). Even at 5 C, the electrode delivered a high capacity of 784.5 mA h g−1 with a capacity retention of 81.1% after 200 cycles (Fig. 12l). These methods of recycling waste rubber materials are expected to achieve sustainable practical LSB systems in the future. Recently, Yan et al. [209] prepared sulfur-rich vulcanized clay rubber (SRVCR) with a sulfur content of 75 wt% by vulcanizing cis-1,4-polyisoprene. The SRVCR polymer was used as a cathode material for LSBs, which solved the serious capacity decay problem at low temperatures caused by the high crystallinity of the discharge intermediate (Li2S2/Li2S) and enabled LSBs to operate at low temperatures. The electrochemical reaction of the SRVCR cathode is different from the traditional LSB reaction mechanism. It formed a new mechanism with Li2S6 and Li2S3 as the discharging intermediates during the cycle, which makes the discharge process undergo a completely amorphous transformation process. Therefore, the LSB based on this polymer showed an improved electrochemical performance at room and low temperatures. Even at a very low temperature of –40 °C, the battery can still operate well and maintain a capacity of approximately 67% compared with that at room temperature. This research makes the LSB concept based on sulfur-rich polymers an excellent application potential in space, polar exploration, and other low-temperature conditions. (2) Inverse vulcanization copolymers Char and Pyun et al. [210,211] pioneered the concept of inverse vulcanization for synthesizing polymers from elemental sulfur and organic monomers originating from petrochemicals, such as olefins and alkynes. The copolymers prepared by this method have a high sulfur content (Fig. 13 a) and can be processed by either solution or melting. The prepared poly (S-r-DIB) copolymer made from sulfur and 1, 3-diisopropenylbenzene (DIB) was used as an active cathode material for LSBs and the effect of the composition of the cathode on the electrochemical performance of the battery was studied. When the sulfur content in poly (S-r-DIB) was 80 wt%, the Li-S cell possessed a high specific capacity and the residual capacity was 823 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles. Furthermore, they demonstrated that the optimized LSB maintained an excellent discharge capacity after more than 500 cycles. They propose that these organic sulfurs inhibit the irreversible deposition of insoluble discharge products, such as Li2S3, Li2S2, and Li2S, and the mechanism differs from the traditional strategies of encapsulating sulfur to suppress the dissolution of linear polysulfides. This research proposes a new way of studying cathode active materials for LSBs. Since then, synthesis methods involving inverse vulcanization and the preparation of new sulfur-containing polymers have been intensely studied [212–215]. This method can be extended to a variety of unsaturated comonomers, including divinylbenzene [216], 1,3-diethynylbenzene [217], 1,4-diphenylbutadiyne [218], styrene [219], bismaleimide [220], eugenol allyl ether [221], triallyl isocyanurate [222], tetra(allyloxy)-1,4-benzoquinone [223], 4-methyl-5-vinylthiazole [224], limonene [225], myrcene, and diallyl disulfide [226], and the resulting sulfur-containing copolymers have high sulfur contents of up to 70 wt% with high capacities and long cycle stabilities as cathode materials [166,224]. In addition, apart from olefins and alkynes, almost all organic small molecules or macromolecules containing functional groups that can react with sulfur radicals can be copolymerized with elemental sulfur to form new sulfur-containing polymers, such as benzoxazine (Fig. 13b) [227–230], terephthalonitrile (Fig. 13c) [231–233], trithiocyanuric acid (TTCA) (Fig. 13d) [234–236], 3-butylthiophene (Fig. 13e) [237], alkenyl, or sulfydryl decorated conductive polymers (Fig. 13f and g) [238–241]. Although sulfur-containing polymers have advantages such as high sulfur contents and capacities, they are still not comparable in conductivity to highly conductive sulfur hosts materials, such as graphene, CNT, and porous carbon. Therefore, to improve the conductivity of electroactive materials, LSBs with high rate performances can be prepared by further combining sulfur-containing polymers with conductive host materials. For example, the electrochemical cycle life and rate capacity of poly (S-r-DIB) can be significantly improved by introducing conductive agents, such as MoS2 [242] and carbon onion [243], during the inverse vulcanization copolymerization of DIB and elemental sulfur. In particular, Hu et al. [244] filled CNTs with poly(S-r-DIB) (Fig. 14 a) to inhibit the dissolution of LiPSs by physical and chemical double confinement. The obtained S-DIB@CNT hybrid cathode exhibited excellent long-term cycle stability. High capacities of 880 and 647 mA h g−1 were maintained at 1 C after 100 and 450 cycles, respectively, which corresponded to capacity retentions of 98% and 79%. In addition, the Coulombic efficiency was close to 100% (Fig. 14b). Yu et al. [225] studied the effect of the nanoconfinement of commercial carbon black, porous carbon spheres, and cellulose membrane-carbonized self-supporting carbon paper on the electrochemical performance of sulfur-limonene polysulfide (SLP) which has a sulfur content of 59 wt% (Fig. 14c). The produced SLP-based composites all exhibited relevant (dis)charge capacities of more than 1000 mA h g−1 at a current density of C/2, with nearly no decay over 200–300 cycles, and significant cycle stabilities. The freestanding carbon paper-SLP electrode with a mass loading of 3.0 mgSLP cm−2 delivered a high initial discharge capacity of 956 mA h g−1 at C/2 and maintained a capacity of 932 mA h g−1 after 300 cycles (Fig. 14(d)). Therefore, the capacity retention rate was approximately 98%, corresponding to a decay rate of as low as 0.008% per cycle, and the average Coulombic efficiency over 300 cycles was 99.9%. Even at a mass load of approximately 7.0 mgSLP cm−2, the electrodes still showcased promising discharge capacities and cycling stabilities. Chen et al. [235] obtained highly crosslinked copolymer composites by the in-situ polymerization of sulfur and TTCA on the surface of rGO nanosheets (Fig. 14e). The resulting cp(S-TTCA)@rGO hybrids delivered high rate capacities of 1341, 1220, 1017, 861, 807, and 645 mA h g−1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 5 C, respectively. More importantly, after 500 cycles at 1 C, cp(S-TTCA)@rGO retained 81.72% (671 mA h g−1) of its initial specific capacity. Chang and Manthiram [245] synthesized a covalently grafted polysulfur-graphene nanocomposite (polySGN) through vinyl functionalization of rGO and in-situ inverse vulcanization. The polySGN cathode had a sulfur-loading as high as 10.5 mg cm−2 and yielded high initial discharge capacities of 1135, 992, and 827 mA h g−1 at C/20, C/10, and C/5, respectively. After 100 cycles, the preserved capacities were 760, 717, and 642 mA h g−1. Moreover, the polySGN cathode showed long-term cycling performance with a low-capacity fade rate of 0.18% per cycle over 300 cycles at C/5. Likewise, Sung et al. [246] immobilized the S-DIB copolymer on oleylamine-functionalized rGO (O-rGO) (Fig. 14f). The as-prepared nanocomposite (poly SOrGO) delivered an initial capacity of 1265 mA h g−1 and retained 81.7% at 0.5 C after 500 cycles. Geng et al. [247] grafted a sulfur-containing polymer poly(S-r-IDBI) onto CNTs via an inverse vulcanization method, which maintained the 1D characteristics of CNTs and effectively established a porous network by overlapping (Fig. 14g). This structural feature facilitates electron transport in the composite and suppresses the shuttle effect of polysulfides. At high rates of 1C, poly(S-r-IDBI) had a low initial specific capacity of 342 mA h g−1, which decreased to below 276 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles. Thus, the CNT-g-poly(S-r-IDBI) composite exhibited a high initial specific capacity of 742 mA h g−1, which was maintained at 465 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles (Fig. 14h). In a broader context, the well-known host materials that effectively immobilize sulfur by physical effects are applied to sulfur-containing polymers to synergize the physical limitation and chemical fixation or covalently connect it to graphene [248], CNTs [249], MXene, porous carbon, carbon quantum dots, and new high conductivity 2D materials to achieve powerful cooperation, which is expected to become the design direction of cathode materials for practical high-performance LSBs. In summary, polymer sulfur hosts with polar groups or side chains have great potential in reducing the shuttle effect of LiPSs. Future work could focus on the molecular engineering of polymers and construction of multi-component nanostructures to improve the capture ability of LiPSs, enhance kinetics, and increase the sulfur content. Electroactive sulfur-containing polymers not only have all the advantages of element sulfur but also have the characteristics of a molecular controllability, structural diversity, flexible macromolecular segments, multi-electron reaction, high electron/ion conductivity, and facile recycling. At the same time, they take into consideration high sulfur-loading and sulfur utilization. However, their LiPS capture ability and structural stability still need to be improved by molecular engineering, such as polysulfide chain lengths, functional linkers, polar groups, heteroatom doping, conjugation effects, and topological structures. The differences in the structure and functional group characteristics of different polymers will make the sulfur-containing polymers produce electrochemical energy storage mechanisms that differ from elemental sulfur. These mechanisms need to be clarified in future research. In addition, the development of controllable, low-cost, and large-scale synthesis methods should also be considered [185]. Meanwhile, for all polymer sulfur cathode materials, even conductive polymer-based sulfur cathodes, their conductivity and adsorption capacity for polysulfides are still weaker than metal compounds and nanocarbon cathode materials at high sulfur-content. Therefore, to improve the electronic conductivity of sulfur cathodes, it may be necessary to incorporate high conductive materials into polymer-based hosts. Combining sulfur-containing polymers with nanostructured CNTs, graphene, porous carbon, and metal compounds to construct a hierarchical sulfur cathode material is a promising means to enhance the electrode conductivity while taking into consideration the high capacity, long cycle stability, and high rate performance. 4 Importance of high sulfur-content in lithium sulfur batteries High-sulfur-content is of great significance to LSBs. This is because previous studies have shown that a high sulfur content (exceeding 70 wt%, proportion of sulfur in the total weight of the cathode materials) and sulfur-loading (exceeding 5 mg-sulfur cm−2) is important to ensure the performance advantage of LSBs over LIBs, especially in terms of their volumetric energy density [29,31,250,251]. Considering this, we summarized some representative high sulfur-containing cathode materials of LSBs in the last decade in Table 1 . The cathode materials with high sulfur contents prepared by early researchers typically only achieved a high initial capacity (1000 mA h g−1) and excellent rate performance, whereas the preparation technology of electrode materials with high capacity, long cycle stability, and high rate performance has been continuously improved in recent years. This indicates that the obstacles of LSBs in practical applications are steadily being overcome. However, high-sulfur-content LSBs still face significant challenges. Due to sulfur's non-conductive properties, the transport rate of ions/electrons slows with an increase in sulfur content, resulting in a slow reaction kinetics for LSB. Second, at a very high sulfur content, virtually no single material or strategy can perfectly solve the issue of the shuttle effect and the slow conversion of LiPSs. The slow conversion of LiPSs will result in the accumulation of soluble LiPSs, resulting in the shuttle effect and a rapid capacity decay [286,287]. In addition, the preparation of high-sulfur-content cathode materials is frequently accompanied by higher production costs, which hinders the commercialization of LSBs on a large scale. To solve these issues with high-sulfur-content LSBs, it is necessary to improve the sulfur cathode material and the lithium-sulfur reaction mechanism. Utilizing ultra-high conductivity materials, designing a new composite cathode material structure that considers both conductivity and sulfur content, and introducing adsorption and catalytic materials that can accelerate reaction kinetics are optimal methods for improving the sulfur host. In addition, when modifying sulfur hosts, it is important to use as many inexpensive sulfur host raw materials and catalysts as possible, to develop simple and inexpensive synthesis strategies, and to design composite structures that are simple to process. Combining multiple functional materials and design strategies is an essential method for enhancing the performance of LSBs with high sulfur content. For the improvement of the Li-S reaction mechanism, it is necessary to develop a sulfur cathode active material with a new reaction mechanism based on an in-depth understanding of the reaction principle and reaction kinetic characteristics of the sulfur cathode, which is currently at the forefront of research in the field of LSBs. Wan et al. [288] discovered, for instance, that replacing S8 in the positive electrode with S2−4 could completely prevent the dissolution of LiPSs into the electrolyte, thereby resolving the shuttle effect issue ten years ago. Moreover, Yan et al. [206] discovered that when PDATtS was used as the cathode active material for LSBs, the electrochemical reaction of PDATtS and Li+ only produced RSLi and Li2S or Li2S2, completely avoiding the problem of rapid capacity decline caused by the formation of soluble LiPSs and their severe shuttle effect in conventional LSB, and realizing dendrite-free LSB. These new lithium-sulfur reaction mechanisms have greatly encouraged researchers to create LSB cathode active materials with superior performance. In particular, Kalra et al. [289] have recently developed monoclinic γ-sulfur instead of the commonly used α-sulfur (orthorhombic sulfur) as the cathode, carbon nanofibers as the current collector, and commercial carbonate as the electrolyte. Without coating or limiting the sulfur, the capacity was stable at 800 mA h g−1 in the first few cycles and had a cycle life of 4000 cycles. Throughout the 4000 cycles, monoclinic sulfur was reversibly converted to Li2S, without formation of polysulfide intermediates. This research overcomes the key obstacles to the application of LSBs. It is believed that LSBs will be commercialized in the near future. 5 Progress and perspectives on the commercialization of lithium-sulfur batteries With the advancement of cathode materials, electrolytes, and lithium metal anode, as well as the LSB mechanism, the specific capacity and cycle performance of Li-S coin cells have been significantly enhanced. However, the commercialization of LSBs must ultimately be implemented as pouch cells or soft-packaged cells. The performance difference between commercially available LSB packs and coin cells is enormous. In spite of this, the commercialization of LSBs has made significant strides in recent years due to their superior energy density. In 2010, Sion Power Corporation of the United States created a 350 W h kg−1 high energy density LSB pack that powered an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) and set a standard for LSB development [290]. In 2020, OXIS Energy ltd created a new LSB prototype with an energy density of 471 W h kg−1 (0.1 C) and a cycle life of 60 to 100 cycles [291]. Wang's research team [292] at the Academy of Military Science has prepared various sulfur-containing battery electrodes with varying capacities. The 2.4 A h battery's electrode contained 4.8 mg cm−2 of sulfur, and the E/S ratio was 3.3. Charged at 0.2 C and discharged at 0.4 C, the specific energy reached 390 W h kg−1, which can be cycled 100 times; The electrode of the 8.5 A h battery had a sulfur loading of 5.2 mg cm−2, and the E/S ratio is 2.2; when charged and discharged at 0.1 C, the specific energy reached 575 W h kg−1. Since 2017, the Zhongke Paisi Energy Technology Co., Ltd. research team [291] has developed a new Li-S prototype battery with an energy density of 609 W h kg−1. The battery's discharge-specific energy reaches 400 W h kg−1 at −20 °C, and it can continue to function in an extremely cold environment of −60 °C, demonstrating significantly better low-temperature performance than LIBs. Additionally, the battery's continuous discharge rate exceeds 4C, and its instantaneous pulse discharge rate can reach 10C. The battery was successfully tested by a solar-powered UAV flying at a high altitude, allowing the UAV to achieve long-duration continuous flight and marking a significant advancement in the practical application of LSBs. Li et al. [293] recently developed a 700 W h kg−1-level rechargeable Li-S pouch cell. Three cycles of stable operation of the pouch cell were used to update the mass-energy density record of LSBs. Consequently, the current mass-energy density of commercial Li-S secondary batteries can reach 400–700 W h kg−1 (≤0.1 C), whereas the average cycle life is less than 100 cycles. The issue of low cycle life restricts the practical application of commercial LSBs to specific fields such as UAVs. Consequently, no large-scale commercial products are available on the market. The slow pace of large-scale commercialization is primarily attributable to the different assembly processes of pouch cells and coin cells; good electrochemical performance of coin cells does not necessarily equate to excellent pouch cell performance. Commercial pouch cells must still overcome numerous obstacles. In most published works, the sulfur cathode has a high porosity and an E/S ratio greater than 15 μL mg−1 [291], resulting in a high liquid injection volume (30%–50%). This prevents the battery from achieving an adequate actual energy density. In practical applications, more attention should be paid to sulfur concentrations above 80%, area sulfur loadings above 7 mg cm−2, and E/S ratios below 5 μL mg−1 [294,295]. Second, despite the growing emphasis on the production of high sulfur content and high sulfur loading electrodes, long-term cycling tests of these sulfur electrodes are typically conducted with low sulfur area loadings [291]. Under high areal sulfur loadings, the cycle life is frequently short. To achieve a high energy density, commercial applications require a high sulfur area loading. In addition, this is the reason why the current commercial LSB prototype battery has a short cycle life. Therefore, additional work is required to improve the electrochemical utilization of sulfur so that the battery has long-term cycle stability in the presence of a high sulfur loading. Thirdly, security concerns are crucial. Due to the differences in battery assembly processes, the potential minor safety of coin cells may be exponentially increased in pouch cells [32]. Due to the enormous volume expansion change of the sulfur cathode, its structure is particularly susceptible to collapse during the cycle. In addition, because lithium metal was used as the anode of LSB, the growth of lithium dendrites in pouch cells poses a significant safety risk. In order to solve the problem of safety hazards, it is necessary, prior to commercial use, to suppress the growth of lithium dendrites from the perspectives of lithium metal interface design and matrix accommodation of lithium metal, in addition to solving the problem of volume expansion of the cathode. Finally, the issue of cost should be resolved for commercial applications. The large-scale commercial production of LSBs must be simple and inexpensive. Therefore, future academic and industrial organizations must concentrate on material synthesis and soft-package battery engineering with high production capacity. With the cooperation of academic and industrial organizations, the commercialization of LSBs on a large scale should become a reality. 6 Summary and outlook With the rapid development of LSB technology, considerable progress has been made in the development of new sulfur cathode materials. By reviewing the sulfur host materials developed in the past decade and the corresponding sulfur cathode preparation technology, we determined that CNTs, graphene, porous carbon materials, metal compounds, and polymers have played a prominent role in the field of high-performance LSBs owing to the particularity of their physical and chemical structures, as shown in Fig. 15 . The excellent cathode material structure design ensures the excellent performance of these sulfur host materials. On the premise that the sulfur cathode obtains high electrochemical performance with sulfur-loading, these sulfur host materials all show their respective advantages and disadvantages. Low-dimensional carbon nanomaterials, such as CNTs and graphene, have good electrical conductivity, providing electronic channels and ion channel interfaces to allow sulfur to efficiently react at the interface. The surface modification and encapsulation of these low-dimensional carbon nanomaterials can improve the sulfur-content, the immobilization and catalytic conversion of polysulfides to achieve high-performance LSBs. In addition, high flexibility and easy assembly characteristics make them suitable for constructing flexible and self-supporting LSB electrodes. However, the high cost of material preparation has greatly limited their commercial application. Moreover, under the condition of high sulfur-loading, the uneven dispersion of sulfur in CNTs and graphene makes it difficult to effectively suppress the shuttle effect. Additionally, the complex surface–interface chemical reaction process inside the electrode is still unclear and the synergistic mechanism of CNTs or graphene with other materials remains largely unknown. Therefore, the large-scale preparation, cost reduction, sulfur utilization rate of the materials, and reaction mechanism requires further investigated. Porous carbon materials are traditionally used as cheap conductive carriers that have broad industrial application prospects. Porous carbonaceous materials, such as microporous or mesoporous carbon, multi-stage porous carbon, and hollow carbon, exhibit large specific surface areas and rich pore structures, which can achieve high efficiency sulfur storage, provide limited space for the sulfur reaction, adsorb polysulfides, and limit the shuttle effect. However, the sulfur-loading capacity of these porous carbons needs to be further improved and the sulfur utilization efficiency and stability should be enhanced to achieve commercially available high energy density LSBs. Metal-based compounds show good potential in high-performance LSB applications owing to their metal-like conductivity, structural diversity, and abilities in efficient chemisorption and catalytic conversion of LiPSs, which is conducive to achieving high capacity, a long cycle life, and good rate performance of LSBs. However, the development of LSBs based on metal compounds, especially metal carbides, borides, nitrides, phosphides, and MOFs reported in recent years, is still in its infancy. Future research should focus on understanding the mechanism of the adsorption and catalysis of LiPSs, chemical modification and surface regulation to improve their performance, and exploring inexpensive metal compound species with high stability and good electrochemical performance. The synthesis process of nearly all metal oxides, precursors of MXenes, most metal phosphides, and a few metal sulfides involves a calcination stage at high temperatures. This increases the manufacturing cost of LSBs based on metal compound sulfur hosts. Therefore, metal compound-based LSBs need to be studied further before they can be commercialized. Polymers have attracted increasing attention in the research of cathode materials for LSBs because of their low production cost and the high tunability of their structures and functions. In particular, sulfur-containing polymers with good electrochemical activity, an adjustable sulfur chain length, and abundant functional groups provide LSB materials with a variety of special properties, making it possible to achieve a LSB cathode with low cost, high sulfur content, and high electrochemical lithium storage performance. However, compared with CNTs, graphene, porous carbons, and metal compounds, the conductivity of polymers under high sulfur-loading is still not desirable. Therefore, it is necessary to combine sulfur-containing polymers with high-conductivity sulfur host materials, such as carbon nanomaterials and metal oxides, to effectively enhance their conductivity, increase their sulfur utilization, and improve their battery rate performance. In brief, it is easy to prepare high sulfur content cathode materials and it is not difficult to prepare LSBs with high capacity. However, for LSBs to be applied commercially, more efforts are needed to lower their cost and improve their battery performance with regards to battery capacity, sulfur utilization, cycle stability, and rate performance. Hence, fabricating an electrode material with a high utilization rate of sulfur, sulfur-loading, and energy density, as well as excellent cycling and rate performance to meet the requirements of practical application, is still an urgent problem. Despite these challenges, the latest advances in cathode materials of LSBs are encouraging for a rechargeable battery revolution. coredata.dc:description: Lithium sulfur batteries (LSBs) are recognized as promising devices for developing next-generation energy storage systems. In addition, they are attractive rechargeable battery systems for replacing lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) for commercial use owing to their higher theoretical energy density and lower cost compared to those of LIBs. However, LSBs are still beset with some persistent issues that prevent them from being used industrially, such as the unavoidable dissolution of lithium polysulfide intermediates during electrochemical reactions and large volume expansion (up to 80%) upon the formation of Li2S, resulting in serious battery life and safety limitations. In the process of solving these problems, it is necessary to maintain a high sulfur content in the cathode materials to ensure that the LSBs have high energy densities and excellent cycle performance. In this review, the novel preparation methods and cathode materials used for preparing LSBs in recent years are reviewed considering the sulfur content and cycle performance. In addition, the problems and difficulties in practically applying cathode materials are described, and the development trend is discussed.
